questions.question: Question 1: Transovarial transmission is a feature of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
Transovarial transmission is a feature of Orientia tsutsugamushi which causes scrub typhus. Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod 
to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in 
trombiculid mites. It is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari. The image below shows a trombiculid mite. Trench fever (option D) is caused by Bartonella quintana.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 36-year-old trekker presented with fever, headache, and rashes following a tick bite. He was 
later diagnosed to have Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following statements is 
false about the microbe implicated?
questions.explanation:
Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. A cell wall is present in rickettsial 
organisms. Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are unable to 
grow in cell-free media and are thus cultured in yolk sacs of embryonated eggs. They are 
non-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They reproduce by 
binary fission and are transmitted by arthropods like ticks and lice (except Coxiella burnetii and 
Bartonella henselae). The rickettsiae are localized in endothelial cells of small blood vessels (except Ehrlichia and 
Anaplasma) in humans. They cause endothelial cell enlargement and degeneration, predisposing 307 
Sold by @itachibot to thrombus formation. Tetracyclines, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones are effective against this 
group but, beta-lactams are ineffective.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true regarding endemic murine typhus?
questions.explanation:
The vector for endemic murine typhus is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. Endemic murine typhus is cuased by Rickettsia typhi (option B) while epidemic typhus is caused 
by Rickettsia prowazekii. The zoonotic reservoir for R. typhi is the rat. Humans are infected 
when flea feces contaminate pruritic bite lesions. Transmission can also occur via inhalation of 
aerosols of dried feces of rickettsemic rat flea. No man-to-man transmission occurs. Patients 
present with fever, chills, vomiting and a maculopapular rash that is more prominent on the 
trunk. Diagnosis is by serology and treatment is with doxycycline. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, 
they develop fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation. The scrotum becomes enlarged and 
the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen. This is known as the Neil-Mooser reaction. It is 
positive with Rickettsia typhi (option D) and negative with Rickettsia prowazekii. The image below shows the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.

questions.question:
Question 4: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod 
infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease? 299 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Louse (image B), Pediculus humanus corporis, transmits epidemic typhus. Gaol fever/ Jail fever/ epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. 308 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old man from Kashmir presents with fever, chills and rash for 1 week. The rash 
appeared on the 5th day of the fever starting from the trunk and progressing to the limbs. 
Epidemic typhus is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the 
disease?

options.b: Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescent form
options.c: Rash is present on palms and soles

questions.explanation:
Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles. Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus 
corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through 
infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in 
poor unhygienic or cold conditions. Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth 
day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In 
some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the 
lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated leading to 
recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease). Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod 
to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii and 
R. akari. Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary 
syphilis and hand, foot, and mouth disease The image below shows the rash of epidemic typhus. 309 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline. To treat scrub typhus, oral doxycycline 100 mg is given twice daily for 7â€“15 days. In the case of 
pregnant women, oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days may be used as doxycycline is 
contraindicated in pregnancy. Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a 
trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 
The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite 
bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with 
fever, headache, myalgia, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia. Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction 
used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of Proteus strains 
OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK alone is agglutinated in scrub typhus.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He gives 
a history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. On 
examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of the 
following arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?
questions.explanation:
A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular 
rash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus. Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite. 
Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults. 
In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferred 
where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated. 310 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A wildlife photographer presents with a blackish lesion at the site of an insect bite from a few 
days back. He also gives a history of fever. A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins 
was observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In the above clinical scenario, a history of insect bite followed by the development of a 
characteristic eschar at the site of the bite and a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins 
suggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for 
agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2, and OX K. The basis of the 
test is sharing an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of 
Proteus. DISEASE

questions.question:
Question 9: A veterinarian presents with new-onset mitral regurgitation and fever. An echo reveals valve 
vegetations and blood cultures show no growth. Q fever is suspected. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding the organism implicated?
questions.explanation:
Coxiella burnetii is the causative organism of Q fever. It is transmitted by ixodid ticks in 
animals; however, it is not transmitted to humans via ticks. Coxiella burnetii is a filterable, obligate intracellular pathogen. They are gram-negative but are 
better stained with Gimenez, Giemsa stains. They are heat resistant and hence survive Holder's 
method of pasteurization. Q fever is a zoonosis and the primary source of human infection are infected cattle, sheep, and 
goats. It spreads through the inhalational route. Veterinarians are at higher risk due to increased 
exposure. Acute disease resembles influenza, nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis. 
Chronic disease presents as culture-negative bacterial endocarditis in patients with valvular heart 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presents with redness of the eye and foreign body sensation. On examination, there 
is follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderately abundant exudates. Chlamydial 
infection is suspected. Which strains could have caused this condition?

options.b: Serotypes A, B, Ba and C

questions.explanation:
Redness, foreign body sensation with follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderately 
abundant exudates suggests inclusion conjunctivitis which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis 
serotypes D to K. 311 
Sold by @itachibot Inclusion conjunctivitis is a type of acute follicular conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatis 
serotypes D to K. The infection is transmitted to the eye from genitals, or contaminated swimming 
pools. Patients present with foreign body sensation, redness and mucopurulent discharge. On 
examination, there is acute follicular hypertrophy of the lower palpebral conjunctiva and fornix, 
non-tender pre-auricularlymphadenopathy and superficial keratitis in upper half of cornea. C. trachomatis is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria. It cannot produce ATP. It 
causes a variety of human diseases (ocular and genitourinary) and has two main biological 
variants: â€¢ TRIC biovar which causes trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC biovar). This is further 
divided into 12 serological variants: â€¢ A, B, Ba, C serovars which cause blinding or endemic trachoma â€¢ D to K servovars which cause inclusion conjunctivitis â€¢ LGV biovar (L1, L2, L3 serotypes) which causes lymphogranuloma venereum

questions.question:
Question 11: A thick, yellowish discharge is noted from the eyes of a five-day-old neonate in the step-down 
ward during rounds. An iodine-stained smear of the exudates is positive for large cytoplasmic 
inclusions as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about the organism 
responsible for the above condition? 302 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a thick yellowish discharge from the eye showing iodine-stained 
inclusion bodies is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. As 
chlamydia is a bacteria, it possesses both DNA and RNA. Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. They 
are filterable like viruses. They are called energy parasites as they lack enzymes for ATP synthesis. 
They cannot grow on artificial media but can grow on cell lines like McCoy, HeLa, or the yolk sac 
of the chick embryo. Chlamydiae occur in two forms, the elementary body and the reticulate body. The extracellular, 
infective form is called the elementary body. The intracellular, non-infective, growing, 
and replicative form is called the reticulate body. These are found inside a membrane-bound 
compartment called the inclusion body which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by 
iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell wall of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading 
to pleomorphism. 312 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A poultry worker was admitted to ICU with severe pneumonia. Bronchoalveolar lavage was 
done; it showed Levinthal Cole Lillie bodies. Which of the following is the causative organism 
for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Pneumonia in a poultry worker with Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies on bronchoalveolar lavage 
specimens is suggestive of psittacosis. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells 
including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. C. psittaci can be 
transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected birds or by inhalation of aerosols from 
avian feather dust. Psittacosis presents with fever, chills, muscular aches and pains, severe 
headache, hepatosplenomegaly and gastrointestinal symptoms. Severe pneumonia may develop. It 
is treated with tetracycline.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient presented with painful swellings on both sides of the groin as shown in the image. 
The clinician suspects lymphogranuloma venereum. Which is the most common serovar 
causing the above condition? 303 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused most commonly by Chlamydia trachomatis LGV 
serovar L2. LGV is a sexually transmitted disease, characterized by suppurative inguinal adenitis.

questions.question: Question 14: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum?
questions.explanation:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The 
most common presentation is the inguinal syndrome, which is characterized by painful inguinal 
lymphadenopathy. 313 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: Lesion scrapings from a genital ulcer show numerous polymorphs, but no bacteria. Which of 
the following is the most appropriate culture medium for organisms responsible for the above 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical scrapings from a genital ulcer showing polymorphs in the absence of bacteria is suggestive 
of chlamydial infection and the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells (human synovial 
carcinoma cell line). C. trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite that 
appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show 
leucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to 
isolate the organism. Option B: Thayerâ€“Martin agar is used for isolation of Neisseria spp. Option C: Robertsonâ€™s cooked meat is used for the culture of anaerobes, especially Clostridia Option D: Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth is used to culture Mycoplasma spp. and 
Ureaplasma spp. Note: Abnormal urethral gram stain showing >10 PMNs/1000Ã…~ field in women with dysuria 
but without coliform bacteriuria supports the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of mucopurulent cervical discharge. 
Gram staining of the discharge revealed numerous pus cells, but no organisms. What is the 
investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this infection?
questions.explanation:
Mucopurulent cervical discharge for 3 days is suggestive of acute cervicitis. As gram stain does not 
show any organism, gonococcal infection is less likely. In this case, Chlamydia trachomatis is the 
most likely organism. For C. trachomatis, the investigation of choice is the nucleic acid 
amplification test (NAAT). NAATs are the most sensitive tests to detect chlamydia. These tests also have a high specificity 
comparable to culture, and in contrast to culture, do not depend on viable pathogens. Therefore, 
NAATs are generally considered the test of choice for chlamydia and have replaced culture as the 
diagnostic gold standard. Mucopurulent cervicitis is the inflammation of the columnar epithelium and subepithelium of the 
endocervix in women. Its commonly caused by Neiserria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia 
trachomatis.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following microbes is also referred to as Eaton's agent ?
questions.explanation:
Eaton's agent refers to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Eaton was the first to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Because it was filterable, it was 
considered to be a virus previously. It was formerly known as PPLOâ€“ Pleuro pneumonia-like organism.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 20-year-old military recruit presented with fever, sore throat, and non-productive cough 
which showed no improvement with beta-lactam antibiotics. X-ray showed peribronchial 
pneumonia with thickened bronchial markings. Primary atypical pneumonia is suspected. 
Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism responsible for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
314 
Sold by @itachibot The above clinical scenario of fever, non-productive cough, no improvement with beta-lactam 
antibiotics along with X-ray features showing peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchial 
markings is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumonia, also known as primary atypical pneumonia or 
walking pneumonia. Mycoplasmas are not obligate intracellular parasites. They are free-living bacteria devoid of cell 
walls. They are highly pleomorphic, with no fixed shape or size. Because of their plasticity, they can pass through bacterial filters and have often been 
mistaken for viruses. Mycoplasmas do not possess spores, flagella, or fimbria. Some species exhibit gliding 
motility. Mycoplasmas are gram-negative, but are better stained by Giemsa stain.

questions.question:
Question 19: Dieneâ€™s method of staining is used for which of the following organisms? 305 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Diene's method is used for mycoplasma. Mycoplasma shows a â€˜fried-eggâ€™ colony on Dieneâ€™s method of staining. The central dark bluish 
area represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates 
superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

questions.question: Question 20: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics. Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as 
these drugs act on the cell wall. 315 
Sold by @itachibot Spirochetes
